Obfuscate the following passage so it can only be understood by someone with a C2 CEFR understanding of English. Use long words while preserving as much of the meaning as you can. Put the rephrased passage in rephrase tags <rephrase>like this</rephrase> so that it can be automatically extracted by an inference script.

<passage>
TO Sherlock Holmes she is always the woman. I have seldom heard him mention her under any other name. In his eyes she eclipses and predominates the whole of her sex. It was not that he felt any emotion akin to love for Irene Adler. All emotions, and that one particularly, were abhorrent to his cold, precise, but admirably balanced mind. He was, I take it, the most perfect reasoning and observing machine that the world has seen; but, as a lover, he would have placed himself in a false position. He never spoke of the softer passions, save with a gibe and a sneer. They were admirable things for the observer—excellent for drawing the veil from men's motives and actions. But for the trained reasoner to admit such intrusions into his own delicate and finely adjusted temperament was to introduce a distracting factor which might throw a doubt upon all his mental results. Grit in a sensitive instrument, or a crack in one of his own high-power lenses, would not be more disturbing than a strong emotion in a nature such as his. And yet there was but one woman to him, and that woman was the late Irene Adler, of dubious and questionable memory.

I had seen little of Holmes lately. My marriage had drifted us away from each other. My own complete happiness, and the home-centred interests which rise up around the man who first finds himself master of his own establishment, were sufficient to absorb all my attention; while Holmes, who loathed every form of society with his whole Bohemian soul, remained in our lodgings in Baker-street, buried among his old books, and alternating from week to week between cocaine and ambition, the drowsiness of the drug, and the fierce energy of his own keen nature. He was still, as ever, deeply attracted by the study of crime, and occupied his immense faculties and extraordinary powers of observation in following out those clues, and clearing up those mysteries, which had been abandoned as hopeless by the official police. From time to time I heard some vague account of his doings: of his summons to Odessa in the case of the Trepoff murder, of his clearing up of the singular tragedy of the Atkinson brothers at Trincomalee, and finally of the mission which he had accomplished so delicately and successfully for the reigning family of Holland. Beyond these signs of his activity, however, which I merely shared with all the readers of the daily press, I knew little of my former friend and companion.
</passage>

<rephrase>
To the perspicacious Sherlock Holmes, she is perpetually designated as the preeminent female. I have infrequently encountered him referring to her by any alternative appellation. From his perspective, she utterly obscures and transcends the entirety of her gender. This was not indicative of his experiencing any sentiment analogous to romantic love for Irene Adler. All affective states, and that specific one with particular intensity, were utterly repugnant to his frigid, meticulously precise, yet astonishingly equilibrated intellect. He was, I postulate, the most flawless ratiocinative and observatory apparatus ever to have manifested in the world; however, in the capacity of an amorous participant, he would have inevitably situated himself in a profoundly untenable and spurious position. He never alluded to the more tender passions except with derisive mockery and contemptuous scorn. For the individual dedicated to scrutiny, such emotions were estimable phenomena—superlatively efficacious for divesting the obfuscations from men's underlying motivations and consequent behaviors. Yet for the disciplined logician to permit such incursions into his own exquisitely calibrated and delicately balanced temperament was to introduce a profoundly distracting variable, one which could potentially cast a pall of doubt upon the entirety of his cerebral conclusions. Particulate debris introduced into a sensitive mechanism, or a minuscule fracture in one of his own high-magnification lenses, could scarcely be more disruptive than a potent emotion infiltrating a psyche of his particular constitution. And notwithstanding this verity, there existed for him a singular female, and that individual was the deceased Irene Adler, of nebulous and equivocal recollection.

My recent interactions with Holmes had been exceedingly sparse. The circumstance of my matrimony had gradually engendered a mutual estrangement. My own consummate felicity, coupled with the domestic preoccupations that invariably proliferate around a man who initially apprehends his own sovereignty over a household, proved sufficiently absorbing to command my undivided attention; meanwhile, Holmes, who harbored an abhorrence for all manifestations of conventional society with his quintessentially Bohemian spirit, persisted in occupying our former lodgings on Baker Street, immersed amidst his antiquated volumes, and oscillating in a weekly cycle between the stimulant cocaine and his own innate ambition, between the soporific torpor induced by the narcotic and the ferocious vitality characteristic of his acute disposition. He remained, as was his custom, profoundly captivated by the systematic examination of criminal activity, channeling his immense cognitive faculties and extraordinary powers of perception into the meticulous pursuit of evidential traces and the elucidation of enigmatic cases which the official constabulary had consigned to the category of irredeemably hopeless. Intermittently, I would receive nebulous reports concerning his endeavors: of his summons to Odessa to address the Trepoff homicide, of his resolution of the peculiar tragedy involving the Atkinson siblings in Trincomalee, and ultimately, of the diplomatic mission he executed with such discretion and efficacy on behalf of the reigning Dutch monarchy. Apart from these manifestations of his ongoing engagements, however, which I merely consumed in concert with the general readership of the periodical press, I remained largely uninformed regarding the activities of my former friend and associate.
</rephrase>
